awd_titl_txt: CPS: Small: Numerical and Symbolic Techniques for Verification and Synthesis of Cyber-Physical Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Next generation Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS), such as automotive systems, require tight integration between the software and the physical world to satisfy the ever-increasing requirements. Unintended behaviors of such cyber-physical systems might lead to loss of property or worse scenarios and hence should be avoided by performing formal analysis of CPS. Such analysis is challenging as the tools for reasoning about the physical world primarily use real-analysis and algebra whereas the tools for reasoning about software uses discrete mathematics and algorithms. Traditional approaches for formal analysis of CPS primarily use algebra, which do not scale well with the increase in the number of variables. This project explores a new algorithmic framework for rigorously reasoning about cyber-physical systems by bridging the gap between the algebraic properties of the physical world and algorithmic foundations of the software.

The techniques developed in this project will exploit the property of superposition principle that is widely observed in the physical world. By analyzing a sample set of behaviors of CPS, these algorithms can infer properties of a large subset of all possible behaviors. The project extends safety verification techniques to linear systems with inputs and parameters, and develops a new notion of counterexample for safety violations of state feedback controllers. The investigators explore a simulation-guided synthesis framework for synthesizing a controller that meets both safety and liveness specifications. The investigator will incorporate research results into undergraduate and graduate classes to introduce students to embedded systems and control design. Additionally, the algorithms and software developed in this project will be disseminated broadly.

por.por_cntn:
Cyber-Physical Systems, the systems that interact with the physical space and are controlled by a computer are all pervasive. From the automatic gear transmission in our vehicles, to battery power managers in the smart phones, these are deployed all around us. In future, such computer guided smart systems are going to be integrated into further avenues of life such as transportation (in the form of autonomous vehicles), energy (managing between renewable and non-renewable sources of energy), and healthcare (medical devices such as pacemakers and insulin pumpus). Since these systems are integrated into such crucial aspects of daily lives, bugs in these systems can cause heavy loss of property and life.

This proposal is aimed at developing new tools and techniques for systematic development of Cyber-Physical Systems. Development and debugging of these systems is especially a challenge given the interactions between physical and digital spaces. As a part of this proposal, the PI has developed important tools that help the system developer to provide rigorous certificates that can be used for certifying Cyber-Physical Systems, help the developer in the development process during the debugging and development phase, and finally, helps the system designer identify the various design patterns for improving efficiency of these systems.

This proposal has also helped the PI to create the next generation work-force by engaging in various teaching and outreach activities. First, the graduate students who are well versed with these techniques have completed industry internships and helped in the technology transfer of these techniques. Second, the undergraduate students studying at UNC Chapel Hill have been exposed to various tools for performing such rigorous analysis of such software systems. Third, the PI has interacted with high school and middle school students and encouraged them to pursue computer science as an area of study and help improve the diversity of the students studying computer science.
